Stem: Robust, light green, hollow, waxy-looking, spotted with purple to reddish-brown blotches.
Leaves: Alternately arranged large 30-50 cm long triangular in outline but very deeply divided giving fern-like appearance. Have acrid smell if crushed.
Flowers: Typical carrot family (Apiaceae) flowers, large clusters of many small branching white flowers arranged in circular pattern giving overall umbrella like shape.
FruitSeeds: Small, oval shaped 2.5-4 mm long with 10 ribs. Containing up to 40000 of more microscopic seeds.
Habitat: Riparian areas, waste areas, roadsides, pastures, stockyards.
DistinguishingFeatures: Differs from Wild carrot (*Daucus carota*) and others in carrot family in being much larger and with purplish blotches on stem.
Impacts: Highly toxic when ingested and can easily kill humans by poisoning.
